statement:
Let $h \colon {\mathbb R}\to {\mathbb C}$ be a bounded measurable
function. If $h$ satisfies the *averaging condition* $$\lim_{c \to
+\infty} \frac{1}{c} \int_0^c h(t) \,d t=0$$ then $$\lim_{\omega \to
\infty} \int_a^b f(t)h(\omega t) \,d t=0$$ with $ -\infty <
\! a < b < \! +\infty$ for any $f \in L^1[a,b]$

Obviously we only need to prove the lemma when both $h$ and $f$ are real
and $0=a<b<\infty$.

Let $\mathbf 1_{[a,b]}$ be the indicator function of the interval
$[a,b]$. Then
$$\lim_{\omega \to \infty} \int_0^b \mathbf 1_{[a,b]} h(\omega t) \,d t= \lim_{\omega \to \infty} \frac{1}{\omega} \int_0^{\omega b} h(t) \,d
t=0$$ by the hypothesis. Hence, the lemma is valid for indicators,
therefore for step functions.

Now let $C$ be a bound for $h$ and choose $\epsilon$ $>0$. As step
functions are dense in $L^1$, we can find, for any $f\in
L^1[a,b]$, a step function $g$ such that
${\left\Vertf-g\right\Vert}_1<\epsilon$, therefore

$$\begin{aligned}
\lim_{\omega \to \infty} {\left\vert\int_a^b f(t)h(\omega t)\,d t\right\vert}  &
\leqslant & \lim_{\omega \to \infty} \int_a^b {\left\vertf(t)-g(t)\right\vert}
{\left\verth(\omega t)\right\vert} \,d t + \lim_{\omega \to \infty} {\left\vert\int_a^b
g(t)h(\omega t) \,d t\right\vert}
\\ & \leqslant & \lim_{\omega \to \infty} C{\left\Vertf-g\right\Vert}_1 < C\epsilon\end{aligned}$$

because $\lim_{\omega \to \infty} {\left\vert\int_a^b
g(t)h(\omega t) \,d t\right\vert}=0$ by what we have proved for step
functions. Since $\epsilon$ is arbitrary, we are done.
